sections.title: Personality & Work Style
sections.description: Help us understand your natural tendencies and preferences to provide personalized career insights

questions.text: After a challenging, high-intensity week at work, what recharges you most?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: Extroverts seek social connection, introverts seek solitude. Both are valid.

questions.text: When learning something new, which approach appeals to you more: (A) concrete examples with step-by-step instructions, or (B) big-picture concepts and underlying patterns? Explain why.
questions.scoring_guidance: (A) = Sensing, (B) = Intuitive. Look for specificity in their explanation.

questions.text: When making an important decision, do you tend to rely more on logical analysis and objective criteria, or on how the decision will affect people and relationships? Give a recent example.
questions.scoring_guidance: Thinking = logic first, Feeling = people impact first. Example quality matters.

questions.text: Describe your ideal work environment: Do you prefer to have things planned and settled with clear structure, or keep your options open and adapt as new information comes in?
questions.scoring_guidance: Judging = structure/planning, Perceiving = flexibility/adaptation.

questions.text: When you're under intense pressure or stress, what's your instinctive response: (A) over-prepare and worry about details, (B) take charge and push through with action, or (C) withdraw to think and analyze the situation?
questions.scoring_guidance: Maps to Enneagram stress patterns. Look for self-awareness.

questions.text: What drives you most in your work: achieving excellence and being the best, helping and connecting with others, or understanding complex systems and how things work?
questions.scoring_guidance: Achievement = Type 3, Connection = Type 2, Understanding = Type 5. Multiple motivations valid.

questions.text: Describe your ideal workday structure. Be specific about hours, types of tasks, breaks, and flexibility.
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: self-awareness, honesty about needs, practical systems

questions.text: When you disagree with a teammate on an important decision, what's your instinct: address it directly and immediately, think it through privately before discussing, or try to find compromise to avoid confrontation?
questions.scoring_guidance: No right answer. Look for awareness of their pattern and context-appropriateness.

questions.text: How do you prefer to learn new technical skills: hands-on experimentation, structured courses or tutorials, reading documentation, or watching others do it first?
questions.scoring_guidance: Learning style reveals cognitive approach. All are valid.

questions.text: Rank these work values from most to least important to you: autonomy, impact, mastery, connection with people, and stability. Explain your top choice.
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for clear hierarchy and articulated reasoning. Reveals core drivers.

sections.title: AI & Systems Thinking
sections.description: Understanding your ability to work with and orchestrate AI systems

questions.text: How does the Internet work? Explain it to someone who's smart but non-technical.
questions.scoring_guidance: Technical: routers, packets, DNS, protocols. Non-technical: cat pictures, web browser. Look for clarity of explanation + depth of understanding.

questions.text: Do you currently do any 'vibe coding' or AI-assisted development? If so, please describe your process and give a few examples of things you've built or other ways you've used it. If not, describe how you currently use AI tools (if at all).
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: specific tools, actual examples, workflow integration, comfort level. No AI use is fine if honest.

questions.text: What's the difference between prompt-engineering and agentification? When would you use one vs. the other?
questions.scoring_guidance: Prompt = one-shot instruction. Agent = autonomous, multi-step, tool-using system. Look for understanding of complexity threshold.

questions.text: Design a multi-agent system to handle customer onboarding for a SaaS product. What agents would you create, what are their responsibilities, how do they hand off between each other, and what could break?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: clear agent boundaries, thoughtful handoff design, awareness of failure modes, realistic complexity assessment.

questions.text: When should you NOT use AI agents? Give 3 specific scenarios where a simple prompt, traditional code, or human decision-making is better than an agent-based approach.
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: cost awareness, simplicity preference when appropriate, understanding of agent overhead, human-in-loop needs.

sections.title: Professional Background
sections.description: Understanding your experience and career trajectory

questions.text: How many years of professional experience do you have in your current field? What roles have you held, and what was your career progression?
questions.scoring_guidance: Extract: years of experience, role progression, field clarity. Used for score weighting.

questions.text: On a scale of 1-10, how technical are you? (1 = no coding experience, 10 = senior engineer). Then give a specific example that demonstrates your technical capability at that level.
questions.scoring_guidance: Score matters less than example quality. Look for honest self-assessment + evidence.

questions.text: Where do you want to be in 3 years? Be specific about the role, skills you want to develop, and impact you want to have.
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: clarity of vision, alignment with strengths, realistic ambition, growth mindset.

sections.title: Culture & Self-Awareness
sections.description: Understanding your work style and growth mindset

questions.text: What's a joke format, meme, or type of humor that makes you irrationally annoyed? Why does it bother you?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: specific taste, articulated reasoning, not taking self too seriously. Red flag: 'humor is unprofessional'

questions.text: What's a weakness or limitation you've successfully compensated for? What system, tool, or strategy did you build to work around it?
questions.scoring_guidance: Look for: honest weakness (not humble-brag), specific compensation system, ongoing management. Red flag: 'I have no weaknesses'
